--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> The section on Minimizing Dimensionality in the paper "Efficient
> Evolution of Neural Network Topologies says this:
> 
> "TWEANN algorithms typically start with an initial population
> of random topologies [2, 7, 21, 22]. Such topological
> diversity must be introduced from the start because new structure
> frequently does not survive in these methods, which do
> not protect innovation. However, it is not clear that such 
diversity
> is necessary or useful. A population of random topologies
> has a great deal of structure that has not withstood a single
> Fitness evaluation. Therefore, there is no way to know if
> any of such structure is necessary. It is costly though because
> the more connections a network contains, the higher the number
> of dimensions that need to be searched to optimize the
> network. Therefore, with random topologies the algorithm
> may waste a lot of effort by optimizing unnecessarily complex
> structures.
> In contrast, NEAT begins with a uniform population of networks
> with no hidden nodes. Because NEAT protects innovation
> using speciation, it can start this way, minimally, and
> grow new structure only as necessary. New structure is introduced
> incrementally as structural mutations occur, and only
> those structures survive that are found to be useful through
> Fitness evaluations. This way, NEAT searches through a minimal
> number of weight dimensions, significantly reducing the
> number of generations necessary to find a solution." 
> 
> You talk about starting minimally and only adding structure that is
> "useful" or "necessary"...not "neutral" structure.
> 
> You say only those structures that are found to be *useful* 
survive. 
> But that's not necessarily true, according to the discussion on 
this
> list.  At least, they are not useful in the sense of contributing 
to
> the fitness of an individual.  If you mean neutral in terms of
> affecting the fitness of an individual, but useful in terms of
> providing building blocks for later innovations, fine.  But that's
> definitely not clear from the literature, and in fact seems a bit
> contradictory.
> 

You know I have to admit the paragraph could have been phrased 
better.  The idea is that in the limit (over a long period of 
generations) for the most part only the useful innovations survive.  
Of course there is always a chance something might survive that 
didn't do well but that would be a fluke of stochasticity.  

But yes I think neutral additions are useful in a number of 
situations.    Note that neutral mutations are totally different 
from random structure in the initial population that haven't 
withstood a single fitness evaluation, since in general, neutral 
additions that persist have withstood many fitness evaluations.

> > -"Not contributing to fitness" is different than "reducing
> > fitness."  You are using these terms interchangeably.  
> 
> No, I don't think I did.  I think I've been fairly careful about
> distinguishing between "neutral" structure and structure which 
either
> helps or hurts fitness.  I've used words like "superflous" and
> "unnecessary", but this is not the same as saying such structure is
> maladaptive.
> 
> > If I am
> > stagnating and I manage to add structure that does not reduce
> > fitness, that is a good thing, not a bad thing, because I'm
> > increasing my range of candidate spaces.
> 
> But it increases the search space and slows down network 
activation. 
> And if the payoffs down the road aren't worth the extra expense, 
then
> it *is* a bad thing.  I don't think it is necessarily true that the
> retention of neutral structure is preferrable...I'm not sure it's
> intuitive.  As I've mentioned before, there are other possible
> explanations for jumps out of stagnation.
> 
> My inclination, in general, is to try to keep the search as tight 
and
> lean as possible, and to try to deal with stagnation from the 
fitness
> function side (i.e., attempt to insure a smoother fitness 
gradient).
> 
> > The point with NEAT is that we are trying to get access to good
> > parts of high-dimensional space.  To say that increasing
> > dimensionality is flat out bad is a generalization.  
> 
> Well, I wasn't arguing that point.  I think without proportional 
gains
> in the performance of the algorithm it's bad policy, because there
> definitely is a cost associated with increasing the dimensionality.
> 

Maybe your thinking is affected by the way you were doing large 
numbers of additions at one time.  I think if you think of NEAT the 
way I implemented it, with very slow growth one piece at a time, you 
can start to see the slowly piecing together neutral structure in 
this way is a good idea if you are stagnating.
